questions.question: Question 1: What is the lower limit of the pharynx?
questions.explanation:
The pharynx extends from the base of the skull (basiocciput and basisphenoid) to the lower border 
of the cricoid cartilage. It continues as the oesophagus. Pharynx is a 12-14cm long conical fibromuscular tube forming the common upper part of the air 
and food passages.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the hypopharynx. Which of the 
following sites will not be involved?
questions.explanation: Epiglottis is part of the supraglottic larynx. The hypopharynx is made of 3 parts: • Pyriform sinus • Posterior Pharyngeal Wall • Post-cricoid region

questions.question:
Question 3: On oral examination of a patient with recurrent upper respiratory tract infection, you notice 
that the Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes is enlarged. Which of the following is not included 
in Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring. Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is 
aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring. The masses are: • Adenoids or nasopharyngeal tonsils • Palatine tonsils or simply tonsils • Lingual tonsils • Tubal tonsils • Lateral pharyngeal bands • Nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall 445 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not a part of MALT structures?
questions.explanation:
MALT stands for mucosal associated lymphoid tissue. Retropharyngeal lymph nodes are not a 
part of it. The rest of the structures are a part of Waldeyer’s ring.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are the junior resident in the ENT department performing a posterior rhinoscopy 
procedure on a patient. Where will you locate the pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube?

options.a: 2.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
options.b: 1.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
options.c: 2.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate
options.d: 1.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate

questions.explanation:
The pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube is situated in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx 
1.25cm behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. 446 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: You are observing a tissue sample from the nasopharynx through an electron microscope. 
Which of the following epithelium will you see?
questions.explanation:
The nasopharynx is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. Functionally, it is the 
posterior extension of the nasal cavity. Other parts of the pharynx are lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Fossa of Rossenmuller is the most common site for carcinoma in the nasopharynx.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma which has spread to 
the sinus of Morgagni. Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected due to 442 
Sold by @itachibot the spread into this space?
questions.explanation:
Descending pharyngeal artery does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni and hence least likely 
to be affected. All the other options are contents of the sinus of Morgagni. The sinus of Morgagni is a space between the base of the skull and the upper free border of the 
superior constrictor muscle. The structures passing through the space are: • Eustachian tube • Levator veli palatini • Tensor veli palatini • Ascending palatine artery- branch of the facial artery Trotter's triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads 
laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by: • Conductive hearing loss • Ipsilateral immobility of the palate • Neuralgic pain

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following structures is present in the oropharynx?
questions.explanation:
Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissues seen in the base of the tongue, hence a part of the 
oropharynx. Oropharynx includes: • Base of tongue • Palatine tonsils 447 
Sold by @itachibot • Vallecula • Anterior and posterior pillars • Posterior pharyngeal wall The pharyngeal end of the pharyngotympanic tube and fossa of Rosenmuller is present in the 
lateral wall of the nasopharynx. The pyriform fossa is a part of the hypopharynx.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with oropharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following 
group of lymph nodes does the sentinel node belong to?
questions.explanation:
The jugulodigastric node is the sentinel lymph node and belongs to the level 2 group of lymph 
nodes. This is the node enlarged in both tonsillitis and base of tongue carcinoma as lymphatics from the 
oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain. Level 
Lymph node 1a 
Submental 1b 
Submandibular 2 
Upper jugular 3 
Middle jugular 4 
Lower jugular 5 
Posterior triangle 6 
Anterior group 7 
Mediastinal

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
questions.explanation:
Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its 
contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during 
deglutition or speech.

questions.question:
Question 12: 443 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old woman suffering from iron deficiency anemia presents to you with difficulty in 
swallowing. On examination, glossitis and cheilitis are observed. There are oesophageal webs 
seen on direct laryngoscopy. Which of the following is the most common site for carcinoma to 
develop in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. The 
post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in women suffering from Plummer-Vinson 
syndrome. 448 
Sold by @itachibot Plummer-Vinson syndrome/ Patterson Kelly Brown syndrome is a condition that can occur in 
people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anemia. The triad seen in these patients: • Post cricoid webs • Glossitis • Angular cheilitis Post cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and 
lower borders of the cricoid lamina.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 30-year-old man presents to you with a foreign body sensation in his throat. On 
examination, you notice the impaction of a fishbone in his pyriform sinus. Which group of 
lymph nodes will you find enlarged in case of its infection?

options.a: It is part of the Waldeyer's ring
options.b: Hypertrophies up to the age of 6 years and starts to regress from puberty
options.d: It is surrounded by a capsule

questions.explanation:
Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of 
lymph nodes. The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain. Pyriform sinus lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the 
upper end of the esophagus. It forms the lateral channel for food. The rich lymphatic network of 
pyriform fossa explains the high frequency of nodal metastasis seen in carcinoma of this region. 449 
Sold by @itachibot Adenoids
